ğŸ“¡ Change Data Capture

Real-time change streams with 1000+ concurrent subscribers and zero-blocking architecture.

What is CDC?

Change Data Capture allows you to observe and react to document changes in real-time. Perfect for:

  • Real-time UI updates
  • Cache invalidation
  • Event-driven architectures
  • Audit logging

Basic Usage

// 1. Typed Mode (DbContext)
var users = db.GetCollection<User>();
users.Watch().Subscribe(change => { ... });

// 2. Dynamic Mode (BLiteEngine) â€” v1.11.0
var dynamicCol = engine.GetOrCreateCollection("orders");
dynamicCol.Watch().Subscribe(change => { ... });

Change Types

var subscription = users.Watch().Subscribe(change =>
{
    switch (change.OperationType)
    {
        case ChangeStreamOperationType.Insert:
            Console.WriteLine("New document: " + change.FullDocument.Name);
            break;
            
        case ChangeStreamOperationType.Update:
            Console.WriteLine("Updated: " + change.DocumentId);
            break;
            
        case ChangeStreamOperationType.Delete:
            Console.WriteLine("Deleted: " + change.DocumentId);
            break;
    }
});

Filtering Events

Filter by Operation

// Only watch inserts
users.Watch()
    .Where(c => c.OperationType == ChangeStreamOperationType.Insert)
    .Subscribe(change => { /* ... */ });

Filter by Document

// Only watch specific users
users.Watch()
    .Where(c => c.FullDocument?.Age > 18)
    .Subscribe(change =>
    {
        Console.WriteLine("Adult user changed: " + change.FullDocument.Name);
    });

Async Processing

users.Watch().Subscribe(async change =>
{
    await SendNotificationAsync(change);
    await UpdateCacheAsync(change);
});

Disposing Subscriptions

var subscription = users.Watch().Subscribe(change =>
{
    // Handle change
});

// Later: stop watching
subscription.Dispose();

Scalability

BLite's CDC uses a "Channel-per-subscriber" architecture:

  • âœ… 1000+ subscribers supported simultaneously
  • âœ… Zero-blocking - Slow subscribers don't affect others
  • âœ… Zero-allocation when idle - No overhead without watchers
  • âœ… Transactional consistency - Events fire after commit

Full Example

var db = new DocumentDb("mydb.blite");
var users = db.GetCollection<User>();

// Real-time cache updater
var cacheSubscription = users.Watch()
    .Where(c => c.OperationType != ChangeStreamOperationType.Delete)
    .Subscribe(change =>
    {
        cache.Set(change.DocumentId, change.FullDocument);
    });

// Audit logger
var auditSubscription = users.Watch()
    .Subscribe(async change =>
    {
        await auditLog.WriteAsync(new
        {
            Timestamp = DateTime.UtcNow,
            Operation = change.OperationType,
            UserId = change.DocumentId
        });
    });

// Clean up on shutdown
cacheSubscription.Dispose();
auditSubscription.Dispose();

Best Practices

  • âœ… Use filtering to reduce unnecessary work
  • âœ… Handle errors in subscribers to avoid crashes
  • âœ… Dispose subscriptions when no longer needed
  • âœ… Use async operations for I/O-bound work
  • âš ï¸ Keep subscriber logic fast to avoid backpressure
  • âš ï¸ Don't perform long-running operations in the callback
